title-group.subtitle: A tentative model based on metasynthesis

author-notes.corresp: Mari Kangasniemi, Department of Nursing Science, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Eastern Finland, P.O.BOX 1627, 70211 Kuopio, Finland Email: mari.kangasniemi@uef.fi

abstract.p: Patient’s duties are a topical but little researched area in nursing ethics. However, patient’s duties are closely connected to nursing practice in terms of autonomy, the best purpose of care and rethinking from the patient’s perspective. This article is a metasynthesis (N = 11 original articles) of patient’s duties, aimed to create a tentative model. In this article, a tentative model called ‘right-based duties of a patient’ was constructed. With its aid, a coherent structure of patient’s duties within different roles and objects of a patient can be defined. In addition, the ethical basis, prerequisites, outcomes and risks of patient’s duties can be named. In conclusion, so-called right-based duties of a patient constitute the basic argument. Patient’s duties are not unambiguous for all patients, and the global perspective to duties has been challenged. However, due to both conceptual and practical reasons, rethinking of patient’s duties is needed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Regarding rights and duties in nursing ethics, the established viewpoint has been patients’ rights, 1,2 and duties of nurses and physicians. 3
–6 Despite the importance and centrality of these viewpoints, in medical ethics, 7 and as professed here, in nursing ethics as well, this ‘mainstream’ approach to rights and duties is today untenable: it has been challenged by the rights of nurses 8 and patients’ duties. 7,9

In this article, we have three topical reasons to focus on patient’s duties. The first reason is the best purpose of care. It will be achieved by a multifaceted combination including nurse and nursing-oriented development of care and the organization, 10 –12 but also by patient-orientation, where the patient is an active partner in the care process. 13,14 With compliance on the part of patients in terms of adherence and responsibility for their own care and health 14 the best purpose of care can be achieved from the patient perspective as well.

The second reason is that patients’ rights have been argued by autonomy. 7 A right-based position of a patient is an established point of view in research, and increasingly so in practice as well, 1,15,16 although patient’s rights are still a complicated phenomenon and not fully achieved. 16 –18 This increasing interest has mainly been based on legislation regarding patients’ rights. From an ethical perspective, autonomy should be distinguished from freedom: freedom refers to particular acts, but autonomy to the status of a person 19 – as in the sense of a patient’s status in health care. Thereby autonomy without responsibility is not autonomy, whereas rights and duties are closely connected together: where one has rights, one has a duty to respect the rights of others. 7,19

The third reason is rethinking of patients’ duties. As a phenomenon, patients’ duties are not a new perspective. 20,21 Since the Hippocratic Oath, patients’ duties have been emphasized. 20 When the American Medical Association (AMA) was founded in the 19th century, the first principles of medical ethics and patients’ duties were formulated and widely presented. At that time, patients’ duties included items such as the duty to choose an officially educated doctor and ‘to confine one’s care as much as possible, to one physician’. 20 Nightingale 22 emphasized patient’s duties as well: the patient’s duty was to be a good patient. It is noteworthy that the perspective to patient’s duties has been that of professionals, not of patients. Rethinking of duties from the patient’s perspective is needed, based on patient’s rights, but not limited to rights.
The purpose of this article is to report what can be learned about the duties of a patient. The aim of the study is to create a tentative model of the duties of a patient through metasynthesis.

sec.title: Metasynthesis as a method
sec.p: Metasynthesis was selected as a research method in this study, aiming to create a tentative model of a patient’s duties based on previous research. Metasynthesis is a relatively new qualitative research method for examining qualitative research 23 or research by other types of methods. 24 The aim is critical examination of the results of previous study, and to analyse, compare, interpret and create a synthesis of previous study. 25 The purpose of metasynthesis is to produce and establish a new and contributed understanding on the research topic by accumulation of knowledge from individual studies. 26,27 The purpose is not just to identify similarities in research on a particular topic but, rather, to dig deep under the surface layer in order to increase our understanding. 26

This metasynthesis followed a protocol consisting of seven phases (Table 1), 28 an approach that has been commonly used in nursing science. 26,29 In the first phase the researcher identified an intellectual interest that qualitative studies might shed some light on, i.e. the duties of a patient. Second, researchers made a selection of previous studies for synthesis guided by the purpose of this study: 25 identifying the duties of a patient. Original studies were sought out both electronically from databases (PubMed and EBSCO, 2000–10) and manually from magazines (2000–10: Nursing Ethics, Nursing Philosophy, Journal of Medical Ethics, and Bioethics). Special search strategies were devised for both databases. During the search, the keywords were ‘patient*’ combined with ‘duty’ and ‘duties’, and also combined with ‘responsibilit*’, ‘liability’ and ‘obligation’. In order to avoid systematic language bias, language was not restricted, and to avoid publication bias, the search was supplemented by a manual search. The search process was assisted by a library informatician. The original studies were selected using pre-tested inclusion criteria, which were 1) explicit interest in the duties of a patient, 2) qualitative or theoretical research method 27 (several philosophical frameworks among qualitative research were accepted), and 3) an original scientific paper. The original studies were selected in stages, based on titles, abstracts and entire articles, and the quality of the selected studies was checked using quality criteria as follows: 1) logical structure of research; 2) defined aim of study, explicit; 3) theoretical framework; and 4) conclusion.

sec.p: The third phase of the protocol consisted of reading through the selected studies. 28 True to the nature of metasynthesis, the focus was on detecting any interpretative metaphors otherwise known as key concepts or themes, with special attention on the details of the phenomenon. Aiming to confirm the suitability of studies, a first draft of wholeness was constructed. The fourth phase of the protocol focused on the relation between the studies in order to obtain a synthesis. The themes and their relationships used in each study were identified, these themes were juxtaposed and finally, an initial assumption was made on how the studies were related to each other. In this study, studies were related in a line of argument, i.e. an inference about the set of parts to someone. 26,28,29 The fifth phase involved the ‘translation’ of the studies to each other: the meaning of the text was translated in terms of unique synthesis. An adequate translation compares the metaphors in one account with metaphors in the other accounts included in the metasynthesis. 26,29 In the sixth phase, the researches created wholeness, which is more than implied by the parts by themselves. Finally, as a synthesis, a tentative model of patients’ duties was reported in this article, 26,28,29 including the following figure (Figure 1).

After selection through seven phases, a total of 11original studies were selected (Table 2). From a methodological point of view there was one 30 empirical qualitative study, while the remaining 10 were theoretical literature-based studies. One of the studies was published in a scientific nursing journal and 10 in medical journals. Four of the studies considered patients’ duties in a broad sense 7,9,13,31 whereas seven focused on detailed questions of patients’ duties. 30, 32

sec.title: A tentative model: right-based duties of a patient
sec.p: Based on this metasynthesis of previous studies, a tentative model can be constructed, here referred to as right-based duties of a patient (Figure 1). According to the metasynthesis, patients’ duties are based on rights and grounded on legislation and health care ethics. The prerequisites of patients’ duties can be named. Patients have duties toward themselves, other patients and relatives, health care personnel and society. The duties of a patient have several roles in terms of a patient and a citizen. The outcomes and risks of patients’ duties can be defined.

caption.p: A tentative model: right-based duties of a patient by metasynthesis, complemented by literature-based discussion

sec.title: Ethical basis of patient duties
sec.p: Patient duties are based on legislation and ethics. The legislation basis is basic law in each country, guiding good and respectful behaviour in general. In health care legislation there are some individual statements regarding patient duties, i.e. criminal law in case of duty to avoid infecting other people. 32,37 Based on selection criteria of previous studies, this metasynthesis does not provide more information regarding legislation, although there is a clear need for later research.

The salient ground for patient duties is ethics, 7,9,13,31 although patient duties have been a neglected issue. Patient duties are not taken into account by so-called ‘mainstream medical ethics’. The ethical obligations have been one-sided, with duties falling in a paternalistic manner mainly on health care personnel, whereas the patient as a weaker or more vulnerable party does not have obligations. Ethics in health care has focused on professional ethics, excluding patient duties. Patient autonomy has been emphasized as well, but connected to freedom, not duties. 7

From the point of view of ethical theories, patient duties can be argued by Kantian ethics, where autonomy also includes duty in terms of health questions. From a utilitarian perspective, one may have duties as a patient to take care of one’s health if greater health for others is achieved, or even be allowed to refuse a procedure, where there is little evidence that it will succeed or promote health sufficiently. 7 From a virtue ethical point of view, responsibility of their role is a virtue of a patient. 13

Responsibility as an ethical orientation has been presented as a ground for duty, dividing responsibility into four groups 38 in terms of role, capacity, causality and liability. From the perspective of role responsibility, patients have responsibilities defined by performing their social role, where patients have roles as consumers and co-producers of care. Capacity responsibility focuses on the responsibility associated with a patient’s capacity to understand reason, foresee harm and carry out the behaviours that social norms require of them. Causal responsibility refers retrospectively to a causal relationship between the patient and an error made, whereas liability responsibility refers to an opportunity to learn from, and not repeat, errors. 13 From this role responsibility perspective, a gendered approach has been presented. Responsibility has typically been characterized as women’s ‘natural’ feature as carers, and this has consequences to patient duties in terms of women being more responsible when it comes to health behaviour. 34

sec.title: Prerequisites for patient duties
sec.p: Free will of a patient has been presented as a prerequisite of patient duties. As Buetow and Elwyn 13 have formulated, determinism is incompatible with free will: if a patient lacks free will, there is no rational basis for patient morality. Another prerequisite is that the patient has sufficient capacity 13 or competence 7 to participate in care in terms of power or opportunity to act, understand, reason to foresee harm and carry out the behaviours that social norms require of them. 13

sec.title: Duties as an inpatient
sec.p: Patients have general duties, such as respecting other people, not wasting others time and keeping promises. 7 Patients may have duties in several roles, where they can be directed towards themselves, 7,9,31 relatives, 33,35,37 staff 7,9,31 and society. 7,9,31,36

As inpatients, patients have duties as health care services users and duties regarding their own health and that of others. As users, patients have a duty to seek medical or health advice 7 and access healthcare services responsibly: 9 being on time for appointments and promptly informing if an appointment cannot be kept. 7,31 Patients have a duty to evaluate the need of care by following the principle of adequate care: avoiding emergency services if first aid is not necessary. Patients have a duty to follow any security information given and handle common hospital property with care. 31 They have a duty to respect staff 7,9,31 and treat them politely. 31

In relation to their own health, there is a duty to promote 7 and uphold 9 their own health and be responsible for their own behaviour. 7,30,31 Patients have a duty to define the goals of care, based on their subjective knowledge, and the expected goals and consequences of the care. 7 There is a duty to give updated, extensive 31 and truthful information about themselves, 7 without embellishment and evasion. 9 Patients have a duty to listen to advice and follow given counselling, 7,9,31 and a duty to self-care. 7,30,36

Patients have a duty toward others’ health in terms of other patient and relatives. This means the duty to take into account 7 and protect the health of others. 9,37 As inpatients they have duties to respect other patients, 9 respect their privacy 31 without intervening in the care of others. 9 Protecting the health of other means a duty to avoid spreading infection; this refers not only to persons who know they carry a disease (e.g. influenza, HIV), but also persons who know they are at risk and even those who definitely know they are completely healthy. 32,37 A duty of beneficence towards future children regarding genetic information can be formulated. 33-35

sec.title: Patients’ duties as citizens
sec.p: As citizens, patients have a duty to take publicly-provided medical advice if they are citizens of welfare states. Public health care involves mutual benefit and mutual participation in terms of mutual duties. 9 Patients have a duty to respect the health care system and other patients, 7 and by using public health services, they have a duty to participate in society; for example, by paying taxes. 9 A duty to take into account limited resources and not to use health services casually can be named. As a citizen they may have a civic obligation to follow preventive health measures. 7 In the case of private health care, patients have a duty to pay for all costs of care and treatment they receive. 31

As patients and citizens, they have a duty to give information in terms of improving both their own health and that of others and health care services. Patients have a duty to give general information as feedback 31 and to participate in research 9 in an ethos of voluntariness.

sec.title: Patient duties connected to outcomes and risks
sec.p: In addition to naming and dividing patient duties, phenomena can be defined that are closely connected to patient duties, i.e. the outcomes and risks of patient duties. The outcomes of patient duties refer here to conceivable consequences of patients’ commitment to duties. From a patient point of view, commitment to duties can lead to achievement of better purpose of care. 7,9,31 From a societal perspective, patient duties, or more exactly, commitment to duties can promote national health, 7,9 and even have a financial impact on public health care. 36

Some risks pertaining to patient duties can be named. The risks refer here to patient point of view, where emphasizing patient duties can threaten wellbeing or health. Sufficient competency or capacity is a prerequisite for patient duties. At the conceptual level there are significant difficulties defining limits between competence and incompetence, and in practice, this is an even more difficult question. 7,13 Another risk is the so-called vulnerable patient. The presumption has been that weak or vulnerable groups do not have the same duties as other patients. As Draper and Sorrell 7 pointed out, vulnerable groups are not automatically excluded from obligations; even they have duties like other patients.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: According to the method of metasynthesis 26,27 , we have produced a coherent understanding of patient’s duties. In this metasynthesis we have presented a reconstructed and coherent structure of patients’ duties, with different roles and objectives of patients. In addition, we have clarified and pointed out some salient phenomena that are closely connected to patient duties. They are questions of ethical basis, prerequisites, outcomes, risks and challenges of patient duties.

In our study, we highlight four critical challenges pertaining to patient duties, i.e. ethical and legal basis, vulnerability, global perspective and transforming of patient duties. In this metasynthesis we considered the ethical basis on the phenomenon, due to our research question. Patient duties connected to ethical theories have been briefly presented in previous research. 13,34 If duties are emphasized in the future, the question is, what are the arguments for them? From an ethical perspective, responsibility and duties have typically been gendered, ‘naturalized’ and reduced to behaviour of morally responsible women, especially female nurses. 39 Expanding research to an ethical basis, including gendered perspective to duties, would also give fruitful perspectives to the question of health differences 40 and patient duties.

In addition, is focusing on the ethical basis of patient duties significant? The legal arguments of patient duties have a stable and inevitable nature, but they are complemented by ethical principles and guidelines 2, 15,16 that are observed in health care; for example, in ‘the codes of conduct’ aiming to set norms for patient behaviours. 41 These ‘codes of conduct’ are also an important part of discussion in health care, highlighted not only in legislation, but also in ethics, aiming to increase the ethical importance of patient duties.

Pertaining to legislation an interesting question that Evans 9 considered is that patients have the duty to participate in research. However, scientific legislation and guidelines; for example, the Declaration of Helsinki (1964), have emphasized the voluntariness of research participation. We consider that Evans argument is a complicated ethical issue because it is not possible to define duties like this based on current legislation.

Regarding the ethical basis of patient rights, free will, capacity and competency are noted as prerequisites. 7,13 Alongside these, the question of patient rights cannot be bypassed. As mentioned above, there is a long history of patient duties, but these are based on the interests of health-care professionals. Current ethics and legislation do not allow ignoring the rights of a patient, 18,42 and that has to be a prerequisite of patient duties as well. The so-called right-based duties of a patient discussed here are a sustainable way to promote the purpose of care: the best care for the patient.

The best care for the patient cannot be achieved without patient duties. It is noteworthy that patient duties are not detached from the care process. Care as a process encompasses organizational, nursing and patient factors (including patient duties), and they are linked together. The entire process, including patient duties as well as other factors, should be transparent to all stakeholders. 10,12

The second critical point are vulnerable patients, i.e. patients or groups of patients who, based on physical, mental or social health, are especially at risk of being dependent on health care services 43 –45 and may be prevented from disclosing their own wishes. 44 Vulnerability is typically associated with children, elderly people and other ‘others’, today even to ‘unproductive people’. 45 Do vulnerable patients have similar duties as others? When is a patient ‘absolved’ from duties? What kinds of rights and duties do they have? As Draper and Sorrell 7 pointed out, there is thin red line between duties and vulnerability: vulnerability does not unambiguously mean exoneration, and vice versa.

Third, an interesting issue is patient duties from a global perspective. Due to differing legislation and cultural diversity, 46 –48 patient duties may have large variation regarding significance and emphasis. On the one hand, duties can be understood as part of good (self)care, 13,14 but on the other hand, they can be understood as one of the forms 49,50 which make patients feel guilty. We really need more knowledge in the future to clarify patients’ duties from a global perspective, including legislation and cultural diversity.

Fourth, it is obvious that patient duties will not go away; instead, they will be increased or be transformed. From a practical point of view, the organization of health care will change due to economy, policy, and best practices 51 –53 so that the traditional inpatient role does not apply any more. Self care in terms of monitoring, testing and even diagnosing poses a clear need for rethinking of patient duties. 7,30,36 In addition, due to the current increased interest in lifestyle and healthy choices, patient duties are no longer limited to inpatients. Do these ‘not-yet-patients’ 30 have duties in terms of patient duties? From a theoretical perspective, a mainstream staff-duty approach is not sufficient; there is a need for a more detailed understanding of the rights and duties of all those involved in care: 7,8 transparency and awareness of rights and duties of all parties is the future basis for health care ethics. These changes impact both the education system and practice, giving rise to a need to re-evaluate issues regarding patient duties.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: The reliability of the metasynthesis was improved by cooperation involving four researchers and by using an informatician. The metasynthesis process was presented carefully and in detail, following the principles of research ethics. Based on searches of original studies, there were few studies in nursing science. This bias may weaken the relevance of this metasynthesis for nursing science.

The metasynthesis method has made it possible to connect to previous research, but there is a risk that nuances of original studies are lost when integrating original studies conducted using different research methods. 27 This metasynthesis is based on 11 studies mostly performed using a theoretical method, except of one using a qualitative method. Despite the use of several methods, no contradictions were found; instead, more differences were found in nuances of patient duties. However, these differences provided a broad understanding of a multifaceted phenomenon.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study has given essential information of patient duties: patient duties are a multidimensional phenomenon closely connected to the basic purpose of care. A significant result of our study is that in health care ethics, the dominant perspective to patient duties has been medical ethics, while nursing science is conspicuous by its absence. That is a clear contradiction to the purpose of care. Our three conclusions are as follows: (1) The foundation of patient duties consists of a shared basis of ethics and legislation, condensed to right-based duties of a patient; (2) Metasynthesis as a research method in nursing science is well suited for accumulating knowledge; (3) In nursing science, there is an unambiguous need for both conceptual and empirical research pertaining to patient duties. We suggest that this tentative model could be used as a tool to understand patient’s role in nursing and health care and as a framework for further research.
